senses.de: To control or handle something, often a task or responsibility.
senses.ex: She manages the whole office by herself.

Tips.title: Leadership Context
Tips.description: Often used to describe someone's role in leading a team or project.
Tips.example: He manages the design team effectively.

Tips.title: Personal Responsibility
Tips.description: Implies taking on duties that require organization and oversight.

senses.de: To succeed at doing or dealing with something, usually against the odds.
senses.ex: I managed to get everything done on time.

Tips.title: Overcoming Difficulties
Tips.example: She managed to persuade them despite resistance.

Tips.title: Effort Required
Tips.description: Indicates effort was necessary to achieve the outcome.
Tips.example: He finally managed to solve the complex equation.

senses.de: To make arrangements or decisions related to a job or situation.
senses.ex: As a manager, he manages all the schedules of his employees.

Tips.title: Organizational Skills
Tips.description: Highlights the importance of planning and structuring.
Tips.example: She manages our team's vacation schedule.

senses.de: To control the use of money or resources.
senses.ex: He manages his finances very carefully to avoid going into debt.

Tips.title: Financial Prudence
Tips.description: Suggests careful and wise handling of finances.
Tips.example: They manage their budget to save for a house.

Tips.title: Resource Allocation
Tips.description: Refers to the distribution and usage of resources.
Tips.example: The event manager efficiently managed the supplies.

senses.de: To train and control an animal.
senses.ex: She manages her horse with great skill.

Tips.title: Animal Expertise
Tips.description: Conveys specialized skills in training animals.
Tips.example: The zookeeper manages the lions without fear.

Administer.wordDefinition:
Administer refers to giving or applying something, such as medicine or a test. It usually involves carrying out a task or procedure according to a specific set of rules or guidelines.

To provide a simple example, a nurse may administer medicine to a patient according to the doctor's orders. A hospital manager may manage a team of nurses and ensure that patients receive proper care.

Administer is more specific and task-oriented, while manage is more broad and focuses on overall coordination and leadership.

Control.wordDefinition:
Control refers to having power or authority over something, while manage means to handle or direct something effectively.

For example, a boss may control the employees in a company, meaning they have the power to hire, fire, or give orders. The boss may manage the employees, meaning they direct the employees' work and help them achieve their tasks effectively.

Control is used when there is a need for authority, power, or restriction, while manage is used when there is a need for guidance, direction, and efficiency.

Direct.wordDefinition:
Direct means to give instructions or guidance on what needs to be done, while manage means to oversee and be responsible for the execution of those instructions.

For example, a coach may direct a player on how to perform a specific skill, but it is the player's responsibility to manage their execution of that skill during a game.

Similarly, a boss may direct their employees on what tasks need to be completed, but it is the employees' responsibility to manage their time and resources to complete those tasks.

Direct is applicable when giving instructions or guidance, while manage is applicable when overseeing and taking responsibility for the execution of those instructions.

Govern.wordDefinition:
Govern means to lead and control a group of people, like a government or a country. It involves making important decisions and enforcing laws to guide the actions of the people.

In simple words, govern is used when talking about leading and controlling a whole group, while manage is used when talking about handling and organizing a specific task or group of people.

Handle.wordDefinition:
Both the words handle and manage are used to describe the act of dealing with a situation.

However, handle is more commonly used when talking about physically dealing with something, such as a tool or object. For example, "I can handle this heavy box" or "He has experience handling dangerous machinery.".

Handle is more specific to physical objects, while manage is more general and applied to a broader range of situations involving people or tasks.

Organize.wordDefinition:
Both manage and organize have similar meanings, but there is a difference between them.

Organize means to arrange or put things in order, to structure or systematize information, objects, events, or ideas.

For example, a student organizes their notes by subject or topic, uses highlighters or sticky notes to highlight important points, creates a study schedule, and makes sure they have all the necessary materials before a test.

Manage is applicable in situations where people and resources need to be directed to achieve a specific goal, while organize is applicable in situations where things need to be arranged or structured in a way that facilitates understanding and efficiency.

Regulate.wordDefinition:
Both manage and regulate refer to controlling something, but in different ways.

Regulate means to establish rules or guidelines that govern how something works. It involves monitoring and enforcing those rules to ensure that everyone follows them.

For example, the government might regulate the prices of goods or the quality of services provided by a certain industry.

In summary, managing is about taking control and making decisions, while regulating is about setting rules and enforcing them to ensure consistency and fair play.

Supervise.wordDefinition:
The words manage and supervise both involve being in charge of a group of people or a task, but there are some differences.

Supervising is more about overseeing and directing the work of others. A supervisor makes sure that people are doing what they're supposed to be doing and that they're doing it correctly.

In general, managing is more focused on overall strategy and achieving long-term objectives, while supervising is more about day-to-day operations and making sure that things are moving forward according to plan.

quotes.Text: DJing is my only peace of mind. When the phone is off, I play my favourite songs really loud for myself, and I'm not talking to anyone; I'm not managing anything. It's just, like, a time when I can listen to music.
quotes.Title: American Designer
quotes.Name: Virgil Abloh

quotes.Text: It is by not always thinking of yourself, if you can manage it, that you might somehow be happy. Until you make room in your life for someone as important to you as yourself, you will always be searching and lost.
quotes.Title: American Novelist
quotes.Name: Richard Bach

quotes.Text: Strong managers who make tough decisions to cut jobs provide the only true job security in today's world. Weak managers are the problem. Weak managers destroy jobs.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: Jack Welch

quotes.Text: Leave the President's family business to him. You will have plenty to do without trying to manage the First Family. They are likely to do fine without your help.
quotes.Title: American Politician
quotes.Name: Donald Rumsfeld

quotes.Text: We might be too proud to admit it as guys, but we still need to learn how to manage responsibility, how to face our challenges.
quotes.Title: Canadian Actor
quotes.Name: Ryan Reynolds

quotes.Text: If you are a great manager you have to have a great personality.
quotes.Title: German Athlete
quotes.Name: Ilkay Gundogan

quotes.Text: If a man can't manage his own life, he can't manage a business.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: S. Truett Cathy

quotes.Text: I have been very lucky to get the managers in the world.
quotes.Title: Belgian Athlete
quotes.Name: Toby Alderweireld

quotes.Text: All the managers in the world are here to win games.
quotes.Title: Spanish Coach
quotes.Name: Pep Guardiola

quotes.Text: It's important to feel wanted by your manager.
quotes.Title: English Athlete
quotes.Name: Patrick Bamford
